column11: Review Text

Safari of just over an hour since the jeeps picked us up at the hotel at 14 and 18.30 we were already back at the hotel (with a 45-minute drive to/from the hotel). For me it was the first safari and so novelty always strikes, but without wow. Needless to say, with all the jeeps we did not see the leopard üêÜ. Some elephants, peacocks, buffalo, pelicans, mongooses, deer and crocodiles. We only saw the elephants up close amidst a multitude of jeeps (our driver was good). I have a cell phone zoom that zooms in well luckily. We were on a World Adventures tour

We went on a Yala Safari, and unfortunately the experience was disappointing. When a leopard was spotted, many of the jeep drivers reacted very aggressively, driving extremely fast and without consideration for safety or the animals. It was upsetting to see that they seemed to care only about spotting the leopard, while ignoring other wildlife and the well-being of the park. The reckless driving took away from what should have been a respectful and memorable nature experience. Overall, it did not feel like responsible or ethical wildlife tourism, which was very disappointing.

column8: Worth a visit even though no leopard sighting
column11: The park is a fantastic experience. We had an afternoon safari and our tour guide was great in private jeep with our driver. We saw elephants in herds with babies, lots of monkeys, water buffalow, beatiful birds and even a rare sloth bear. Unortunately no leopard sighting, which there is no guarantee of.  Would have been 5* if we had seen a leopard üòâ

We booked three half-day safaris at Yala NP and they were awesome. The driver Heshan and our guide Sanka were professionals, we were traveling with them daily and booked them through our lodge (Koragaha), they work for several hotels. There were never any problems and we probably saw everything except the bears. Unbelievable also what Heshan could still see while driving. Thanks to the guys‚Äô experience, after waiting 1.5 hours we could see a leopard coming out of the bush right in front of our car without dozens of other vehicles around us. I would definitely book the safari directly with an accommodation, even if it is more expensive than outside. The reasons are quite simple, you not only have a driver, but also a guide with you, you don't have to buy a ticket, you can pass right in the morning at 6 o'clock directly to the gate because registered and booked online by the hotel. 90% of national park visitors can buy their ticket first and are then allowed to queue up in the sometimes very long motorcade on the left at the gate and they also have no guide in the car. We were completely satisfied.

It's definitely worth the trip! On the plus side: if you take a good guide, you will be happy. Animals, birds, plants abound. We drove and turned our heads) saw hare, monkeys, mongooses, elephants, leopards, herds of all kinds of horns. But there are downsides, of course: the biggest downside is a deranged toilet cleaner. First of all, there's no paper in the toilets, wipe your sleeve or not at all, the janitor sits right under the open door of the women's toilet - very unpleasant. If you have to throw away diapers, personal hygiene products or if your child has vomited in a bag and you haven't thrown it in the bushes yet for reasons of conscience - the janitor will literally chase you and break into the booth screaming no-no-no. When asked what to do with this bag, he says take it to the Jeep. You know that's surprising and outrageous. It would be nice if the job description were explained to him... there's a lot of garbage in Sri, and there will be a reserve with such a tourist-oriented nature. The second downside is sometimes unrolled roads, washed out and the jeep dives into a huge puddle or runs parallel to the ground. Other than that, I really enjoyed it and the whole group was excited. We had a wonderful guide and a wonderful driver. Thank you for this opportunity. These are the right zoos)

column8: Amazing Wildlife Experience in Yala National Park
column11: Our safari in Yala was one of the best parts of our trip. We saw elephants, crocodiles, deer, many birds, and were lucky to spot a leopard too. The park is so amazing and the drive through the jungle was exciting from start to finish. A must-visit for nature and wildlife lovers.

We went on a field trip to Yala National Park in awe of everyone, adults and children alike.  We saw almost all the park's inhabitants and most importantly, the star of Yala Park, the Ceylon leopard. It's just great to see animals in their native habitat. Clearly, we recommend everyone especially with children.

column8: Be prepare for bumpy roads, no toilets
column11: Our visit to Yala National Park revealed a rich history; information posters noted that Yala was established as one of Sri Lanka's first national parks in 1938, having originally been designated a wildlife sanctuary in 1900. Yala claims the 3rd position in the world just behind Yellowstone in USA and Banff in Canada. The park is a haven for an impressive array of wildlife, prominently featuring the Sri Lankan leopard (Yala boasts the highest leopard density in the world), Sri Lankan elephants, sloth bears, and mugger crocodiles. Other resident wild cats include the jungle cat, fishing cat, and rusty-spotted cat. Our mid-afternoon safari lasted over three hours, taking us over off-road bumpy terrain. We observed a variety of animals, most frequently peacocks, but also a Bengal monitor, Asiatic wild water buffalos, purple-faced langur monkeys, spotted deers, Asian elephants, mugger crocodiles, a ruddy mongoose, a termite hill gecko, and a leopard resting high in a tree. Despite the excitement of the leopard sighting, the overall volume and variety of animals observed didn't feel commensurate with the extended duration and bumpy nature of the drive. The high volume of tourist jeeps, which often crowd around a single sighting, also impacted the sense of an authentic wilderness experience.

We have seen a lot of different animals. Sometimes you have to take some time to discover the animals. It's just a safari where the animals aren't always in close proximity. But that also makes it exciting!

column8: Always very many jeeps, only recommended in the tourist quiet months
column11: What bothers me about Yala is that the park is totally overcrowded, it was already when I first went there in 2012. Today it is even worse, you have to expect 200 parallel-driving jeeps, which often chase after the leopard little animal-friendly, push each other off the paths or overtake each other. The park is of course very scenic with its location by the sea, but I would recommend it only in the tourist quiet months

We docked in Hambantota Harbour with the AIDA Stella and I booked the trip to Yala National Park. The tyre of the Jeep was already damaged but nobody seemed to care.  I immediately had the impression that the guide wanted to show us a leopard. Elephants or other animals were stopped only briefly or not at all. Then the guide apparently got a radio message that a leopard had been sighted. Immediately, 10-15 jeeps headed that way. There was a lot of pressure, everyone wanted to be the first. Our driver drove recklessly until we finally saw the leopard. A huge jeep ball was created, another jeep drove us into the side and damaged the tire even more. The return trip to the camp could only be done in the crotch mpo.  All the passengers were scared. That's not how I imagined the trip.

In January, we stayed at the Buthawa Bungalow in Yala with a couple of friends and had some wonderful sightings. During the three days we spent at the bungalow within the park we were able to have some close encounters with Leopards. That was definitely the icing on the cake but we also spotted many species of birds and mammals. Established in 1938, Yala National Park is one of the best places to spot wildlife in Sri Lanka. Located on the island‚Äôs south coast, Yala encompasses open grasslands, sand dunes, dense forests and lagoons. Covering an area of 979 square kilometers, here you can find several big mammals like the Sri Lankan Leopard, Sloth Bear and the Asian Elephant in addition to over 180 species of migratory birds that visit the coastal lagoons of the deep south of Sri Lanka during the winter.

We visited during August when the climate was hot and dry, so we decided to do an early morning safari and a late afternoon one. As we were staying at a hotel nearby, the pickup and drop-off were at the hotel. Both trips were really enjoyable and we were lucky to spot a leopard on both. There‚Äôs no denying that the park does get very busy, so it‚Äôs not like a private game reserve in South Africa, for example. You‚Äôre often not seeing animals ‚Äòin the wild‚Äô when you‚Äôre in a queue of 30 or so vehicles, so be prepared for some traffic jams! That said, it‚Äôs a big park so you can frequently find yourselves alone, and it only gets crowded when everyone congregates in an area where something like a leopard has been sighted. Our driver, Chamara, was great: he offered plenty of information along the route, and found leopards on both safari drives, so couldn‚Äôt have asked for more. Yala National Park is undoubtedly busy, but certainly worth visiting for the opportunity to see a variety of wildlife.
Our guide only spent 2 hrs taking us to the park.He kept rushing to possible leopard sightings and didn‚Äôt really slow down yo look at many other birds or animals . It didn‚Äôt seem worth going

A lot of time spent on the slopes, but not much extraordinary to see. You should not compare it with safaris in Africa. We saw a few elephants, pelicans, pheasants, a mongoose, an eagle, a crocodile, some deer, and the animal that all 4x4s are looking for and this in a fortuitous way, on the track on the way out. This ended our ride a little "shaken" in a more positive way. Sri Lankans and tourists alike celebrate this park. My opinion is different, although I commend the effort made to preserve wildlife in their natural environment. We went in low season. In high season, it must be a nightmare. I wouldn't go back, of course.

A great variety of animals.  Not nearly as crowded as other reviews have suggested (except when one jeep spotted a leopard and seemingly all the other jeeps in the park rushed to the spot).  We went for a whole day, which worked well;  contrary to advice, none of the tours saw a leopard in the morning but we did see one at 5.20 at night. One tank we dubbed ‚Äúcrocodile city‚Äù - it had so many crocodiles in it.  They would try to sneak up on storks but failed to catch them;  maybe they succeed sometimes, or there would not be so many. The compulsory lunch stop at a big concrete building next to the beach was very pleasant,  presumably the heavy concrete and steel structure was built to be tsunami proof after the devastating 2006 tsunami wiped out all the coastal area of Yala.
We saw elephants l, crocodiles, many birds, and were lucky to spot a leopard too. The park was beautiful. The safari ride was really fun. Was definitely a great highlight of our trip.

We went in the Katagamuwa entrance (north) as this was recommended as being much less crowded than Yala in the south. We were the first jeep in at 2pm and never saw more than  3 or 4 other jeeps at any time, so no crowds. Seeing the animals you are aiming for is very much "luck of the draw". They are all there but possibly avoid the roads with noisy jeeps. For the first 3 hours we were disappointed. Saw lots of Water Buffalo and Peacocks, a mongoose, monkeys and squirrels and a single elephant. Then in about 30 minutes on the way out we came across a big snake, jackal, crocodile and (what we had dreamed about) a leopard leisurely crossing the road right in front of us and slowly ambling off into the bush. Most of the other jeeps we came across had seen almost nothing, so we were lucky. You pay your money, its not a zoo,  so nothing is guaranteed. Was it value for US$150? For the last 30 minutes a definite YES, prior to that, a no.

I expected more. We opted for a half-day tour according to our structure, but I understood that the quality of the basic Safari will depend on your driver. We definitely preferred Safari to Udawalawe, so in my opinion, if you have little time and you have to decide, I would opt for another park. In fact Udawalawe has several advantages: 1. The price is lower 2. It is located in a less crowded area even in August and therefore there are far fewer jeeps (something really not to be underestimated) 3. There are few leopards, but I found that even in Yala you rarely see them, so, you might as well 4. There are a lot of elephants, more than in Yala, and I had the chance to see them up close 5. I saw a rare 3 month old baby Elephant:) The only memory I have of Yala is a leopard tail glimpsed between 20 jeeps, a few birds and two elephants in the distance. Leopards are many, but they are so hidden that it is not worth going.

Wonderful experience, our guide talked through all the wildlife and we had a break for coffee and cake. What more can you want. Leopard, Elephant, Crocodile, spotted deer, mongoose... loved the experience.

I highly recommend going with Lahiru Prasard (lahiru.jpdk@gmail.com), who knows this park and its wildlife like the back of his hand. We found many rarieties in our day and a half in the park- elephant tusker, two leopards, several hornbills, sambar deer, three species of mongoose, parakeet, several birds of prey, etc. in addition to the ever common water buffalo, Axis deer, langur, crocodiles and monitors. The only thing missing was the elusive sloth bears, which Lahiru went above and beyond looking for. I would highly recommend pairing a visit to Yala with Udawalawe like I did due to its superior elephant viewing and spending at least a full day in the park in order to find as much wildlife as you can.

We had a fabulous two day safari at Yala National Park. We saw some fantastic animals and birds but for our trip we got some very close encounters with the elephants. A great place clearly loved by the rangers and tour guided alike and a must visit for any tourists.

Enjoy an exciting yet relaxing wildlife escape with your loved ones! Our family-friendly Yala tour includes a safe jeep safari, spotting elephants, peacocks, and more. Perfect for kids and adults alike ‚Äî fun, educational, and full of unforgettable memories!

Yala Park was the great disappointment of our trip. We had booked two safaris, one in the evening and one in the morning, and we could not see leopards. And disappointment is not only because of that, it is because of the experience itself. In the park, thickets and low trees abound, and visibility is very limited on both sides of the road. Only occasionally do you open views of a pool or lagoon. In these lagoons you can see some crocodiles and different birds, but larger animals are very scarce. In the two days we only saw three elephants and a small bear for a few seconds, and it was because they were on the track. This causes long queues of jeeps to form immediately with nervous tourists waiting for their turn to see something. In addition, there is no radio communication between the cars, so as it is a large park, the sighting possibilities drop a lot. They are many hours on sandy and bumpy roads, with poor visibility and many SUVs. These also have no bare roof, so you can‚Äôt stretch or cool off. We have done safaris in Africa and any of them far exceeds this one, as you enjoy the views and the animals are easy to see. Sri Lanka is a wonderful country, but don‚Äôt put much expectation on animal viewing safaris (except Mihintale to see herds of elephants) or they will ruin your trip.

We had a wonderful 3 hour safari at Yala National Park in Sri Lanka, and it was truly a memorable experience. The safari was done in a 7 seater canter, which was comfortable and gave everyone a good view of the surroundings. One of the highlights was seeing herds of elephants, including adorable baby elephants walking closely with their mothers. It was an incredible sight to witness them in their natural habitat. We also saw plenty of deer, a variety of birds, and other wildlife throughout the journey. A unique aspect of Yala is that it borders the Indian Ocean, and during the safari, we were able to see the coastline from inside the park‚Äîa rare combination of jungle and beach in one place. There‚Äôs even a small caf√© inside the park where you can take a short break and enjoy the natural surroundings. Highly recommended for nature lovers and wildlife enthusiasts!

If in Sri lanka you have to visit Yala national park. Although we did not see any tigers, we saw lots of other wildlife. We had our own jeep  (which our driver sorted this for us) and we stopped when ever we wanted.

To add some balance to negative reviews: We did everything 'wrong' compared to what the blogs tell you: went in dry season (2nd week of May), booked on the day, did the evening tour, and were so late we only got into the park at 3pm. Our driver didn't even pretend to get our hopes up, just promised to do his best to find us some animals... Within 1 hour 30 minutes we saw multiple families of elephants, got a few feet from a massive bull elephant, had two separate leopard sightings (one 18 yards from the jeep), and saw the most rare creatures in the park - a sloth bear and her cub. As well as the usual crocodiles/water buffaloes etc. We left at 5pm having spotted almost every type of animal in the park. The point is: it's all luck. They're not performers working to a schedule, they're wild animals. We were lucky to get a young, enthusiastic driver who knew which areas to scout and when to split from the crowd - the rest was just chance. Don't go in with unrealistically high expectations, and you'll enjoy yourself.

We had high expectations of Yala National Park, but unfortunately were disappointed. As soon as an animal is spotted somewhere, countless jeeps race there as if on a veritable drive hunt ‚Äì which is neither pleasant nor animal-friendly. We were stuck in traffic for over 45 minutes in the middle of the park. In comparison, our safaris in Udawalawe National Park and Eco Park were much quieter, closer to nature and, above all, richer in animals. If you are looking for real wildlife observations without crowds, you should avoid Yala.

To enter the park, we had to pay $25USDpp and then 13000 LKR plus tip for the half-day Safari experience with a driver. Unfortunately, on our day, we didn't see any leopards. Mostly birds, water buffalo, lizzards, deer. We did see one elephant. We didn't regret the decision to go, but was not fantastic compared to the price paid for the privilege. We take solace only that the fees help pay to protect the animals.

We planned our entire trip around this safari, and it turned out to be one of the biggest disappointments of our travels. As experienced travelers who‚Äôve been on many safaris, we can confidently say this was a complete waste of time and money. The "safari" consists of driving through thick bushes where you can‚Äôt see anything, while your driver sits comfortably in an air-conditioned cabin, leaving you sweating on top of the jeep breathing in toxic diesel fumes‚Äîespecially when 20 other vehicles crowd the same spot. To make matters worse, the driver kept stopping, claiming to see leopards "1 km away" (total nonsense‚Äîwe saw nothing!). Compared to other safaris we‚Äôve done, this was an outright scam. Save your time and money‚Äîavoid this place at all costs!

We visited the park for both an evening and morning safari. On the evening safari we were fortunate enough to have a sighting of a leopard. The jeep drivers were very respectful however there were only 4 jeeps in the vicinity at the time. They allowed us enough time to observe the leopard and their cub. We also saw peacocks, crocs, water buffalo, many birds, spotted deer and others. On the morning safari we could have seen elephants however there was a very large jeep jam and as we had seen many the day before at udawalawe we decided to not to join the join the jam and went I search of other animals. We did not have any major sightings on the morning safari however it was still enjoyable.

What a disappointment and frustration after visiting this park! Not because of the park itself, but because of the way the tours are organized. The environment is beautiful, with lush vegetation, beautiful scenery and lots of birds. Where it spoils is at the level of the visit itself. You get in a 4x4 equipped for safaris but you only follow a single track, the main road for an hour until the air equipped with a snack and tables where dozens of 4x4s are found, and back through the same track passing through a pretty body of water with dead trees. In short, at no time does the driver seek to go towards the animals. If the animals, including the leopard that attracts most visitors, are along the main trail, everything is fine, otherwise we go home very frustrated, especially the view of the park which, again, is beautiful.

Don‚Äôt waste your money. Too many jeeps, nearly 200 hundred per day. Very few animals too see as they are freighting from all the noise from jeeps. Toilet facilities are discussing. Just a park where boys will be boys with their toys. No consideration for customers or animals. Very expensive trip

Yala National Park blew us away! We were lucky enough to spot a leopard within the first hour, along with elephants, crocodiles, and so many exotic birds. The park is absolutely stunning with its mix of forest, grasslands, and lakes

Buffaloes and elephants are the most extraordinary thing we find. We went with 2 guides with a rather ramshackle but ideal Jeep for your tracks. We tried to go almost off-piste but we found no unique species, apart from iguanas, birds, fawns, etc... The park is beautiful, it is not a jungle, and the beach surprises; if you are in the area it is worth it, but take a trip to this destination, in my opinion, no.
We saw lots of amazing animals, but the drivers need to be more considerate of the animals. Was an incredibly bumpy ride!

Good place to see elephants up close, monkeys, beautiful birds, crocodiles and lizards. Unfortunately we were not lucky enough to see a leopard. Few hours touring in Yala was enough time. Lot's of cars and occassionally trafic jams on narrow roads.

Disappointing!! We did the midday tour in the afternoon barely saw fauna, a few monkeys, deer, and some literal birds. There were times when races occurred between the jeeps to pass first and especially when leaving the park. Conclusion a waste of time and money.

if the park wasn't hopelessly crowded. Even our ranger from the Hilton Yala ‚Äòcomplained‚Äô.  Unfortunately, the government probably needs the money and it is not regulated. (There are reportedly up to 600 jeeps in the park during peak season) When a driver spotted a leopard, all the jeeps drove to the spot: Approx. 30 min Traffic jam, a salvageable stuck jeep (as we had four-wheel drive our driver could help) and then the leopard was fortunately still lying on its rock. If you hire only one driver you don't get anything, the driving just and hardly explain. If even then absolutely ‚Äòrent‚Äô a ranger

There are currently over 500 safari trucks allowed in park. The drive is like a race with no respect for the animals. The drivers are more like taxi drivers just after some tourist money. Our drive also included a planned strike, we had no idea what was happening our driver and other drivers just got out of jeeps and left us. Frightening and just appalling. Go to Africa instead if you want to animals happy in their natural environment

It is a very large and beautiful nature reserve, but it did not meet the expectations at all, the value for money is not equivalent, the price for admission is 44 USD and part of it you must hire the Jeep that takes you inside the park for another 50 USD, the tour takes 3 to 4 hours and supposedly you see leopards that I never saw, if you see animals in their habitation which I find beautiful and important, to be able to appreciate elephants without any human mistreating or dominating it with violent forms, without chains. I saw crocodiles, birds, deer, buffalo, eagles, even a dog that makes me think that leopards may not and is what among other things the park offers.  Friends went to another park called Unawatuna the same day and were very happy.

Unfortunately this is written almost 5 yeas since I visited the place. I did go there in June 2020. Since the sited does not permit me to select any beyond one year, I have selected June 2024. A time spent among the wild which I will never forget. For me spending in the wild does not comes as a half day spent inside the jungle, but spending a whole day inside. For me traveling to Yala does not mean that spend a day in Kataragama as a stay over but travel to the destination in the morning and return on the same day evening (approximately 2 1/2 hours  drive each way), thanks to the Southern Express Highway. I did have a super tracker who knew the wild as someone who takes you inside should know. His aim was not only to show us the leopards and the sloth bear but truly show birds and other mammals too. Thank you Lahiru for the great support given with arranging the trackers for our trip. Spent a whole day inside and saw may animals which includes the leopard. But which I had the chance of seeing a sloth bear (which I did but not able to capture as i only saw the feet and the light was too dark).

You need to appreciate that the drives around the park are very busy, eg over 50 jeeps waiting for 6.30 opening. Drivers overtaking at too high a speed and clouds of dust. If an elephant is sighted you can join a two lane queue to see it. This is all a consequence of poor management of entry numbers and timing plus some renegade operators. The animals and birds are superb, obviously it depends on which ones appear and where. So a degree of luck. Remember no food in the jeep unless you want to be raided by an elephant!

Let‚Äôs start with a positive and say that Sri Lanka is beautiful and delightful country to visit and tour, Yala NP was the biggest disappointment of our tour. Prior to booking our tour we had seen the negative reviews but decided to go as it was included. We did two 3 to 4 hour visits, one in the afternoon and one early morning, We did have a few good moments but generally it was too busy, too dusty and too many pot holes so not recommended for those with bad backs or loose teeth, if you didn‚Äôt have them before, you will leave with them. In the surrounding hotels and residential areas of Yala NP, you soon realise that there are hundreds of 4x4 vehicles available for hire, most drivers we saw or heard were not naturalists but taxi drivers for the want of a better expression. Our first driver consulted a chart when we asked for a bird identification, most did not have binoculars just relying on constant mobile calls or stopping to chat to other drivers for info, then racing each other to a prime location. My heart sank when 5 or 6 vehicles surrounded and elephant, no empathy for the wildlife (photo attached).There are also photos of the dawn opening queue and racing vehicles. The park should be a jewel in the crown of Sri Lanka, instead it is open to get as many through the door as possible with no regulation on the suitability of drivers/ guides or their vehicles, a few were stuck or broken down on our visits. Really sorry to write this but do visit and Enjoy Sri Lanka, you will not be disappointed.

National Park since 1938, it is home to 44 mammal species and 215 bird species. It supposedly has the world‚Äôs largest concentration of leopards. Our safari was costly, time-sensitive and not as productive as I had hoped. There were too many jeeps at the time we went with no discernable method to viewing animals. Some jeep drivers made dangerous manoeuvres to access prime spots, constantly on their phone for sightings in order to secure better tips. No leopards this day (although promised) but we did see spotted axis deer and sambars, elephants, peacocks, assorted birds, mongooses, crocodiles, water buffalo and warthogs. Plan to go early and hope to have better luck than we had‚Ä¶.

A great experience, we had a half day safari which we found adequate given the rough terrain driving. We saw many different wild animals, peacocks water buffalo deer etc. and elephants , but unfortunately not a leopard, neve4 mind perhaps next time.

Pick your safari wisely and get your tickets on line to safe waiting in line at the entrance.  An early start and a full day gives you the best chance to see everything and our guide from Kingfisher Beach Resort took us off the well trodden roads and we managed to see 2 leopards.  We also saw so much more and a full day really is the only way to see the area as it is vast.  There are lots of jeeps zooming around but with the right guide you avoid the masses.

Overcrowded and no control measures!! Far too many jeeps on the tracks all racing to get ahead! Not the relaxed experience I would have expected. If one vehicle stops, all others have to stop behind. At one point, over 10 jeeps were stacked up because the one at the front was looking at a leopard that they were lucky enough to spot. By the time they moved, the leopard had gone!! It would work much better if rules were in place to ensure vehicles can‚Äôt stop unless the road is clear behind them! Don‚Äôt waste your time or money at Yala, our experience at Udawalawe was much more relaxed and peaceful. Animals are less skittish and you‚Äôre much more likely to see them!

We visited the park in January and the weather was wonderful. The park‚Äôs vegetation was green and lush. While the epweather was great, the lush vegetation makes it a little more difficult to see animals, though we had success in seeing many elephants, water buffalo, deer, peacocks, birds, and more . Unfortunately we were no able to catch a glimpse of the elusive leopard, though most of our fellow hotel guests at Cinnamon Wild were able to see one on their safaris. It can be very dusty so come prepared with a mask if you‚Äôre sensitive to that. If you are going on an all-day safari, you‚Äôll stop at a casual restaurant from 12-2 when the park is closed. Take cash because they don‚Äôt take credit cards. There is no toilet paper or soap available in the rest rooms so come prepared. This rest area is on the beach so take advantage of a walk on the beach but DO NOT SWIM. The water is very dangerous at that time of day. You must have a an animal tracker with you, who will be hired within the park when you buy your tickets. Be sure to tip both your tracker and driver. The roads can be very very bumpy I wouldn‚Äôt recommend to people with back or neck issues or if you experience motion sickness. The park opens at 6 am. Be there as soon as possible to make sure you‚Äôre one of the first tours in line at the gate. It can be very crowded with trucks and can back up when wildlife is seen. We were so far back in line the animals were gone by the time we made it to the sighting spot. Bring binoculars! You‚Äôll be happy you did.

Imagine you waking up at 4 am to be among the first, at the park ticket office, and among the first at the opening gate at 6, to avoid a long queue of jeeps from 300 to 400 arriving like a flooded river, to be tossed for three hours in the paths of the park, breathing exhaust gas and dust, as all these jeeps cross each other several times, to see what.... Peacocks, cockerels, buffaloes, three annoyed elephants, a crocodile but all this from afar, the leopard usually runs away with all that mess is very rare to see. To me it seems like big business for those who organize these ‚Äúsafaris‚Äù and for the park managers, the real Safaris are something else. On the other hand, the environment is very beautiful, but ruined by off-road traffic.
yala national park was good .we saw the leopard ,,elephants,crocodiles,many kind of birdsand ect.. good jeep and clever drivers..

The visit to Yala National Park was unfortunately a big disappointment. The park is extremely overcrowded with jeeps that are constantly driving around and there is hardly any trace of the original nature. You feel like you're on safari in a crowded theme park instead of in a wild nature reserve. Because of the many vehicles, the animals are far away or hiding and you hardly get to see anything. I had hoped for much more and the price-performance ratio is definitely not right here. The noise and the constant movement of the jeeps make a visit to the park anything but relaxing. I would recommend visiting other parks that are less crowded and where you actually still have the chance to see animals in their natural habitat.

It is a very nice place, the Jeeps were waiting for us only when we arrived. With a lot of nature, we were able to see some animals, understanding that not many, since it does not depend on us and in the end we arrived at the beach, very beautiful

The park itself has nothing to do with my review. Things are going wrong here. I have already been able to go on a safari in another country and I am very disappointed with how the rabbit runs here. Well over 20-30 cars at one entrance. You chase the animals, our driver drove way too fast, the cars are only occupied by 2 people. This alone could have reduced the number of cars. Nobody explained anything about flora or fauna to us. If an animal has been sighted, then briefly stopped, pointed at it and on. We are still in a park here where the animals live and clearly we are encroaching on their space, but zero attention is paid to it. During the break we stood around a pond with 5 and more cars, where the drivers then had a loud conversation. In addition, we were ripped off in terms of price and had to pay 48,000 instead of 24,000 rupies. For one of us cruising the park. Total waste and I am very disappointed. It's a shame.

One of the amazing sanctuaries we have visited in Sri Lanka. We often travel with our son and relatives as we are very fond of nature. We have seen many leopards and bears during the same half day safari and sometimes none. It all depends with timing, the climate and definitely luck! I can assure that even without a siting of an animal the ride can be joyous just staring at the luscious trees, shrubs and the water bodies. A must see if you visit Sri Lanka!

The scenery was fantastic - remote and aside from the necessary tracks it was unspoiled. The animals were hard to find, and I like that, but a great reward when you do see them. They are sufficiently wary. It doesn‚Äôt feel like a zoo. And I like that the vehicles have to stay on the tracks, unlike in African parks. But‚Ä¶.. there are too many vehicles. It spoils the experience for tourists, and it bothers the animals. There were traffic jams! Unbelievable. Yala NP - you need to reimpose a vehicle quota per day. I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôll still achieve the revenue with the high entrance fees.

The format is the same for everybody.  A 3-hour morning safari (6am to 9), and/or a 3-hour afternoon safari (3pm to 6).  Everybody has to be in 6-person open viewing jeeps.  Local tour guides charge about $50-60 to hire a full jeep for a 3-hour session, whereas local hotels charge +$50 per person for the same jeep.  Everybody has to pay park fees which are about $33 per person (only very small children are cheaper). The area in which the jeeps patrol is at the gates and called Block 1, which is along the coast and is about 10 miles by 5 miles.  You will see herds of buffalo at the water, mostly likely some elephants, warthogs, and various birds. The leopards are more elusive, and not guaranteed on every trip.  When one is spotted, many jeeps converge.  We did three trips and saw a leopard in the distance on one, were very close to a leopard on another (standing on a rock), and didn't see one on our third.

We used this company to take us to Yala National Park.  It was very easy to arrange and the driver even picked us up from our hotel which was further out (slightly more but it would have cost.mpre to catch an uber to the park).  The driver, Shamika, was amazing, not sure how he saw the mongoose, the land monitor lizard whilst driving. Very reasonable, and even gave us a cup of ceylon tea that his mum had prepared for him ‚ù§.  Turned up early, was polite and no hidden extras.  Thank you

Yala National Park is a great place to visit, although familiar with a few of the more common animals there which we saw such as the elephants, peafowl, water buffalo, spotted deer, crocodiles, it was the first time seeing some of these creatures in life and not on a documentary. We was also fortunate to whitness a mother leopard and her two cubs less than fifthteen minutes into the National Park. The natural scenery is breath taking, there are huge natural stuctures which look similar to Sigiriya and lakes filled with flowers where elephants swim. We also were able to take a break at the designated area for the wash-room, and if I remember correctly there looked to be a caf√©. This was located close to the beach which is connected to the National Park. There you will find a small built up area with one or two buildings providing these facilities. If you do decide to visit I would recommend doing so early in the morning, so around 5am is when you should aim to be there.

The words cannot describe the beauty and the wildness of this place. if you want to see animals in their real environment (as it should be) this is the place. I would recommend the 4h trip. I think a full day trip would be too large and tiredness.
We visitied this place despite having warned that one cannot see more than a few peacocks, elephants, deers, crocodile and wild pigs. These were the animals which we eventually saw.

We were collected from our hotel at 04.45.  Our jeep driver was lovely and very experienced.  We arrive at the park 30 mins later.  There must have been around 120 jeeps waiting to get in.  Leopards were spotted early on but due to the volume of vehicles and tourists shouting, they shot off and were not seen again. Our guide told us they are allowing far too many vehicles to drive through the park and so now leopards are very diffcult to spot.  Most jeeps were 8-12 seaters with only 2 guests in each one, We did however see elephants, water buffalo, crocodiles and all sorts of birds. An elephant with 2 babies walked right past our jeep - we could have reached out and touched them.  But again, very noisy R*****n tourists actually shouted at them and scared them off. Perhaps some rules should be spoken through, advising folk how to behave.

Long day ,rough roads and far to many vehicles,some animals are scared of vehicles so unless your at front you miss quite a lot Full day you stop for dinner and toilet its absoluetly appalling,make sure you take toilet roll and preferably a bush or tree.....there is lots of money being made from tourists there and some should be put back into that area IMO
